I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to  the  Republic  of  Tajikistan  for  the  CAREC  Corridor  3  (Dushanbe–Uzbekistan  Border) 
Improvement Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  THE CORRIDOR 
 
2.  The Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program has developed a 
transport and trade facilitation strategy and action plan covering short-, medium-, and long-term 
investments across six road and rail corridors across the region. The aim is to improve regional 
connectivity, cut transport costs, and increase competitiveness. The CAREC Corridor 3 covers 
almost 7,000 kilometers (km) of roads and runs in the north–south direction, linking the Russian 
Federation to the Persian Gulf. Tajikistan is one of the key transit points. However, several 
sections in the country are in bad shape and incomplete. Moreover, facilities at border crossing 
points  are  inadequate  and  cross-border  procedures  inefficient.  As  a  small  and  sparsely 
populated country, Tajikistan depends on the corridor for investment, job creation, trade, and 
ultimately economic growth and poverty reduction. Export-driven agriculture accounts for 37% of 
total employment and 23% of gross domestic product (GDP). Aluminum exports are equally 
important. These two activities need the CAREC Corridor 3 to reach regional and international 
markets—the  nearest  seaport  for  Tajikistan  is  more  than  3,000  km  away.  The  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and other development partners have completed rehabilitation of 
close to 90% of CAREC Corridor 3 sections within Tajikistan.2 However, various important 
sections  are  still  unrepaired.  These  stretch  from  Dushanbe  to  the  Uzbekistan  border  and 
amount to 62 km in total—with an estimated investment of close to $200 million. 
  
3.  The  Government  of  Tajikistan  has  asked  ADB  and  the  European  Bank  for 
Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) to finance these corridor sections. The EBRD will 
support one section close to the capital (Avicenna Monument–West Gate section, from km 0 to 
km 5)  and  ADB  will  provide  the  rest  of  the  network  up  to  the  Uzbekistan  border.  The 
government has requested ADB to finance several soft infrastructure components, including 
improving infrastructure and facilities at the Dusti border crossing point with Uzbekistan, and 
project management assistance. The financing plan for the Tajikistan section of Corridor 3 is in 
Table 1.

III.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
4.  The project is part of the government’s 2010–2011 Public Investment Program3 and fits 
with the ADB country partnership strategy for Tajikistan, 2010–2014.4 It is also an integral part 
of  the  CAREC  transport  and  trade  facilitation  strategy  and  action  plan,  2008–2018.5 The 
regional dimension is now fully embedded in national planning in Tajikistan. 
 
5.  Corridor sections. The road from Dushanbe to the border with Uzbekistan crosses the 
Gissar valley and the town of Tursunzade (km 5–km 62)—two busy and growing agricultural, 
industrial, and commercial points in Tajikistan. Gissar has the highest agricultural output in 
Tajikistan, comprising cotton, grain, fruits, and vegetables—all important exports.6 Tursunzade 
is home to Central Asia’s largest aluminum processing plant7 and several small light industry 
clusters—ceramics, brick, cable and cotton-ginning, and cleaning—employing 10,000 people. A 
quarter of Tajikistan’s cross-border vehicles and freight pass through the Dusti border crossing 
point. However, the condition of the road from Dushanbe to the Dusti border crossing point is 
deteriorating and needs rehabilitation. 
 
6.  Sector strategy and reforms. The National Development Strategy, 2006–2015 targets 
rapid improvements to the country’s transport infrastructure, related services, and maintenance. 
A sector road map and investment program supports the strategy. Institutionally, a restructured 
Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) has been mandated to execute investments 
under the road map. The rest of the institutional setup includes legal and regulatory frameworks 
and improved procurement systems. The sector also benefits from the work of various institutes 
covering  design  and  quality  control.  The  budget  process  has  been  refined  and  includes 
systematic provisions for capital investment, operation, and maintenance. The budget has been 
increasing by 18% annually since 2004. A road safety program, 2009–2013 is in place and is 
being implemented satisfactorily. The country’s road accident rate has fallen—it is the lowest 
among the 10 members of the Commonwealth of Independent States. The MOTC is working on 
pilot performance-based contracts for routine maintenance works, which is a new but important 
initiative  in  the  country.  The  objective  is  to  maintain  the  quality  and  life  of  assets  while 
containing costs. The works will be outsourced to the private sector to perform a large share of 
this work. 
 
7.  Despite significant progress in the planning, policy, institutional, maintenance, oversight, 
and funding areas, the transport sector remains affected by several gaps which are summarized 
below. 
 
(i)  Tolling. Road sector investment and maintenance will need the private sector. 
The government introduced tolling on a Dushanbe–Khujand–Chanak (350 km) 
road on 31 March 2010. The performance of this road is being assessed but 
work is at an early stage.

3 
(ii)  Contract  modalities. The public and private sectors require predictable and 
robust contract modalities. The MOTC still applies too many different modalities, 
especially regarding project management, construction, and maintenance. This 
affects transparency, competition, and efficiency. It also limits the private sector’s 
interest in the sector. 
 
(iii)  Road database. Investment and maintenance planning need a good database 
covering traffic count, road conditions, accidents, etc. The current database is 
inadequate and incomplete. 
 
(iv)  Funding. Capital investment and maintenance finance requires substantial and 
predictable funding. The budget has been constrained by the recent economic 
crisis. Although this is improving, much of the funding still relies on external 
sources. A more sustainable system is required, particularly for maintenance. 
Performance-based contracts and road funds are under consideration to address 
this problem. 
 
8.  Under the project, ADB will provide finance to help the MOTC address some of these 
issues. Training will be provided to support work in other areas specified under the Transport 
Sector Master Plan.8 Further, ADB will assist with measures to mitigate specific governance 
risks identified in the sector governance assessment report.9 
 
9.  The project design incorporates the key lessons learned from ADB’s experience in the 
transport  sector  in  Tajikistan  and  other  Central  Asian  countries.  These  lessons include  (i) 
obtaining the government’s financing assurances for adequate funding for maintenance of the 
project road, and for increases in financing of road maintenance; (ii) using advance contracting 
and  retroactive  financing  to  avoid  initial  implementation  delays;  and  (iii)  strengthening  the 
executing agency’s project implementation capacity with provision of consulting services. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The project will increase national and regional trade, and further economic growth. The 
project outcome will be improved connectivity and mobility along the Tajikistan sections of the 
CAREC Corridor 3. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
11.  The outputs will comprise (i) reconstructed and upgraded road sections from Dushanbe 
to Tursunzade to the Uzbekistan border (km 5–km 62); (ii) improved infrastructure and facilities 
at the Dusti border crossing point; and (iii) developed gender and border communities and 
improved road operations. 
 
12.  The first part of the road investment will be centered on the West Gate–Tursunzade 
section (km 5–km 50), which is currently classified category II.10 The project will upgrade it to 
category I—equivalent to a four-lane international design standard along the existing right-of-

way. The works cover road widening, minor realignment, and improvements to pavements, 
drainage structures, and bridges for higher traffic volumes. The second part of the investment is 
centered on the road section from Tursunzade to the Uzbekistan border (km 50–km 62). This 
will be upgraded to category II (from category III), while maintaining the existing two-lane road. 
In both sections, road safety will be improved. This will be preceded by road safety audits, 
review of traffic management and road signing, training, and public campaigns. 
 
13.  The project will also improve infrastructure and facilities at the Dusti border crossing 
point with Uzbekistan. The investments include connecting to a dependable power source; 
modernizing the customs buildings; installing new information technology and other equipment; 
building a new all-weather walkway for pedestrians; and putting in place ancillary buildings and 
facilities for cars, trucks, and people.11 Border guards, customs, and other agencies working at 
the project border crossing point will have better working and living conditions. The border 
crossing  point  will  also  benefit from  better  control  equipment.  Border  management  will  be 
improved through training programs.12 New and more efficient procedures will be introduced to 
assure the efficient movement of goods. 
 
14.  The project includes a gender and border community development program, which is the 
first such program in Tajikistan and will enrich the livelihood of border communities. The plan 
includes investments to improve village access roads, sidewalks, footpaths, footbridges, and 
social  infrastructure  in  selected  border  communities.  Through  direct  financial  and  capacity 
development  support,  the  project  will  encourage  cross-border  trading—involving  women 
entrepreneurs. The road investment will benefit from a program to deal with the spread of 
sexually  transmitted  infections  and  HIV-related  disease  in  the  project  area.  Education 
campaigns will target high-risk population groups such as migrant workers and their families. 
 
15.  Direct support to the MOTC will focus on the following areas: 
 
(i)   Tolling framework. ADB will provide specialist services on this program.  
 
(ii)   Ministry of Transport and Communications website. A new website will be 
set up to show key MOTC activities, new initiatives, and their funding sources. It 
will include current and planned projects; environmental impact assessments, 
and  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plans;  road,  rail,  and  air  transport 
conditions;  traffic  volumes;  accident  and  safety  statistics;  driver  and  vehicle 
licensing and registration; licensed rail and air transport operators; contact details; 
and grievance redress arrangements. The website will also be used to receive 
feedback from the public and other stakeholders. 
 
(iii)   Contract  management.  The  MOTC  will  be  assisted  to  set  up  improved 
contracting  modalities,  contract  processing,  and  contract  performance 
monitoring. 
 
(iv)   Database. Training and support services will be provided to the MOTC to collect 
and update road sector data.

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
19.  The technical due diligence assessment focused on the definition of the investment plan 
and  operation  and  maintenance  arrangements.  Both  are  confirmed  as  viable.  Based  on 
population and traffic growth projections, the corridor sections require widening within the next 4 
years. About 50% of the pavement areas have cracks, potholes, and deformation. Rutting 
averages 5.5–6.0 meters/km measured in accordance with the international roughness index. 
The sub-base is weak and requires urgent investment. The due diligence process confirmed the 
reasonableness  of  the  investment  and  maintenance  plans.  It  also  confirmed  the  technical 
specifications—adoption  of  category  I  design  standards  in  one  section  and  category  II  in 
another. The road alignment, which follows the existing right-of-way, was studied and confirmed 
as valid, thereby minimizing land acquisition and involuntary resettlement. 
 
20.  The due diligence also focused on soft infrastructure, in particular the quality of facilities 
at the Dusti border crossing point. This border crossing point handles 50,000 vehicles per year, 
with an average of about 150 trucks per day. However, the assessment confirmed the facilities 
to be inadequate and without reliable supply of electricity. The due diligence team checked 
customs procedures and concluded that they were inefficient and contributed to long border 
delays.

7 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
21.  The project is economically viable, with an economic internal rate of return of 24%. The 
project road sections will experience 20% annual growth (for goods and containerized transport). 
Annual traffic and cargo growth is projected to increase on average by 9% for trucks, 8% for 
buses, and 11% for cars and minibuses. This is broadly in line with GDP growth of 10% 
projected for the medium term. Annual nationwide border cargo and vehicle movement growth 
rates—vehicle entering, leaving, and transiting—peaked at 16% during 2006–2008. The project 
will increase trade and freight between Tajikistan and Uzbekistan by 20% annually. It will ensure 
lower transport costs and higher export values, and will attract transit traffic by reducing the 
current border crossing time to and from Uzbekistan by 30%. It will generate additional traffic 
from Afghanistan through the Nijni Pyanji border crossing point and from the People’s Republic 
of China through the Kulma border crossing point to Turkmenistan, Turkey, the Caspian Sea, 
and Europe. Benefits accrue through savings in road user costs and travel time, and increases 
in agricultural and industrial production and trade. A risk analysis concluded that the likelihood 
of the economic internal rate of return falling below 12% is less than 10%. The project is only 
moderately sensitive to capital cost increases. The switching value for total traffic is –33%, 
implying that the base traffic could fall by a third before the project becomes unviable.  
 
22.  Trade relations between Tajikistan and Uzbekistan are improving, although some risks 
are possible in this area. Uzbekistan is Tajikistan’s fifth largest trading partner. The CAREC 
transport and trade facilitation strategy is dealing with cross-border and trade issues, including 
harmonization of border and customs regulations and procedures, simplification of customs 
duties and other taxes, and joint customs control. 
 
23.  The MOTC budget, covering capital investments and maintenance, has increased every 
year.  Actual  maintenance  funding  increased  by  34%  during  2008–2009.  With  GDP  of 
$4.6 billion,  $23  million  (i.e.,  0.5%  of  GDP)  is  the  minimum  spending  required  for  road 
maintenance. The MOTC made available $8 million (0.2% of GDP) for road maintenance in 
2010. This budget outlay will increase by about 18%–20% per year during the next 5 years. An 
automated  road  databank  will  help  validate  the  maintenance  budget,  and  a  contract 
management system will contribute to improving sustainability of road projects. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
24.  A road sector governance assessment was completed in November 2009. It reviewed 
the  overall  country  systems,  including  institutional  arrangements,  legal  and  regulatory 
frameworks, public finance management and procurement, and a risk management plan. The 
report  points  out  the  absence  of  legal  certainty  and  a  commercial  vision,  which  integrate 
financial resources with maintenance requirements. It recommends establishing a consistent 
commercial  policy  and  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks  as  prerequisites  to  public–private 
partnership  transactions.  Other  obstacles  include  nontransparent  operations,  outdated 
operational  tools,  and  a  skills  gap.  The  project  incorporates  all  of  the  assessment  report 
recommendations. 
 
25.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to,  and 
discussed with, the Ministry of Finance and the MOTC. The specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM.

8 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
26.  The project is classified as a general and a geographically targeted intervention with 
direct impact on the project area, targeting border communities. An assessment of the poverty 
and social implications was undertaken. It revealed that the project area has witnessed an 
increasing number of households headed by females as a result of male migration. The poverty 
rate for women is high, the number of households headed by women increasing, and formal 
sector jobs for women are few.15 Women need to be encouraged to start small businesses, 
ideally supported with conditional grants and training. A gender action plan has been prepared 
as part of the project-related work, and the PAM details a grant finance scheme. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
27.  The project is classified environment category A because of the road widening section 
from the West Gate to Tursunzade (km 5–km 50). The due diligence confirmed that the project 
does  not  pass  through  any  environmentally  sensitive  areas.  The  MOTC  prepared  an 
environmental impact assessment, examined by ADB and uploaded to ADB’s website on 8 June 
2010. The project has met all public disclosure requirements. Significant impacts associated 
with the project are typical of a road project which includes traffic disruption, traffic noise, 
vibration, and air quality.  Mitigation measures for all impacts are included in, and will be 
implemented through, the environmental management plan. The design features an improved 
road surface, which will lessen traffic noise and limit progressive degradation. 
 
28.  Civil works will entail significant land acquisition and involuntary resettlement impact with 
about  376  households  to  be  affected  because  of  the  road  widening.  The  involuntary 
resettlement is category A. The MOTC prepared a land acquisition and resettlement plan, which 
ADB disclosed on its website on 24 September 2010. The MOTC will be responsible for meeting 
all  ADB  safeguards  requirements.  ADB  will directly  select  an  external  reviewer  to  monitor 
resettlement  and  compensation  progress,  and  provide  training  on  safeguards  to  mitigate 
potential risks. The project affects neither indigenous peoples nor vulnerable groups, and is 
classified  category  C  for  indigenous  peoples.  Positive  economic  and  social  impacts  are 
expected. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
29.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 5 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.16 The integrated benefits and impacts are 
expected to outweigh the costs.

V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
30.  The government and the MOTC have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
will conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and grant agreement. 
 
31.  The government and the MOTC have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
project, which are included in the grant agreement. Disbursement of the grant proceeds will be 
conditional upon payment of compensation and provision of other entitlements under the land 
acquisition  and  resettlement  plan,  and  the  exemption  of  taxes  and  duties  on  project 
expenditures, or allocation of funds for their payment. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
32.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  grant  not 
exceeding $120,000,000 to the Republic of Tajikistan from ADB’s Special Funds resources for 
the CAREC Corridor 3 (Dushanbe–Uzbekistan Border) Improvement Project, on terms and 
conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement 
presented to the Board. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda
